isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - MAJOR STRUCTURAL REPAIR: 9600 - GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS

step1.para: Major repairs should be done in a well equipped repair shop. Pulling devices, air tools, proper riveting equipment and a welding machine will be necessary to do a good job.

For proper alignment, the cab should be set up on a flat surface. The cab in Figure 1 is resting on a simple, rolling dolly. it is helpful to be able to fasten the cab down at different points while making the repairs. Wood 4 x 4's can be used for support. Having the cab at a good height for working will speed up the job.
Take measurements before making any repairs. These measurements will give you a good idea of what needs to be done. Figure 2 shows the alignment specifications for all four 9670 cabs.

Try to square the cab up with some pulls. if you need to, remove some sections to do this, but take out as few as possible. The more straightening you can do with everything still in place, the better.

The engine tunnel is the most critical section of this cab. The shape of the tunnel allows it to clear the engine properly. If it is not returned to the original shape, it will not do this. if it is too badly damaged to be straightened in place, it must be replaced. Figure 3 shows a tunnel with a large fold in its top. This tunnel had to be replaced. Replacing a tunnel will require removal of the dashboards and the bunk floors so as to get at the horse collars.

figure.caption: Figure 3. Tunnel With Damage Fold On Top

step1.para: Damage to the right or left rear corner (common in jackknife accidents) may be repaired by splicing in a new section of the outer sill. Figure 4 shows the splice in place. This splice was welded and backed up by an aluminum plate. You can see the huck bolts used to hold the plate in place.

Damage to the right or left front corners may require more extensive replacement. Figure 5 shows removal of the entire right floor and all the side and front panels on the right side. The tunnel on this cab was heavily damaged and it was also removed.

Whenever you remove sections for repair or replacement, it is important to brace the rest of the cab so that it will hold its shape. In Figure 5 you can see that the roof is held up by a post, and there is a diagonal pulley for further support.
